events.title: Birth of J. P. Morgan
events.description: J. P. Morgan was born in Hartford, Connecticut, United States.

events.title: Morgan's father settles in England
events.description: Junius Spencer Morgan, J. P. Morgan's father, settled in England and lived there for the remainder of his life.

events.title: Morgan sets up his own company
events.description: J. P. Morgan set up his own company, taking advantage of many opportunities to buy and sell in the booming commercial city of New York.

events.title: Morgan marries Amelia Sturges
events.description: J. P. Morgan married Amelia Sturges, who was in the advanced stages of tuberculosis. He gave up all commercial activities and took his stricken bride to Algiers, Algeria, and then to Nice, France, hoping to cure her.

events.title: Morgan forms partnership with Jim Goodwin
events.description: After the death of his first wife, J. P. Morgan formed a partnership with his cousin, Jim Goodwin, and called the firm J. P. Morgan and Company, Bankers.

events.title: Morgan marries Frances Tracy
events.description: J. P. Morgan married Frances Tracy, one of the six daughters of attorney Charles Tracy.

events.title: Morgan tours California
events.description: J. P. Morgan and his wife, accompanied by two relatives, rode the new transcontinental railroad to Utah and to California, where they toured extensively by stagecoach and horseback.

events.title: Morgan partners with the Drexels
events.description: J. P. Morgan accepted a new partnership with the powerful Drexels of Philadelphia. He became a full partner and headed their New York office under the title of Drexel, Morgan, and Company.

events.title: Morgan lends money to U.S. Army
events.description: Morgan lent the U.S. Army money with which to pay its troops, after a distracted Congress had adjourned without setting aside the money.

events.title: Morgan's father dies
events.description: After the death of his father in 1890, J. P. Morgan began buying rare and old works of art on an immense scale.

events.title: Formation of United States Steel Corporation
events.description: In 1901, J. P. Morgan formed the United States Steel Corporation, the world's first billion-dollar corporation.

events.title: Government lawsuit against Morgan
events.description: Theodore Roosevelt, the Progressive president, ordered an antitrust prosecution, contending that the combination of the two railroads would be too powerful and in violation of antitrust law. The government won the lawsuit in 1904, and the merger fell apart.

events.title: Death of J. P. Morgan
events.description: J. P. Morgan died during one of his periods of travel in Rome, Italy.
